file_content.text: It's been an honor serving with you.
Captain... Supreme Chancellor... Kephess is dead and his army is broken. Denova is back under Republic control.
You delivered a message to everyone who thinks they can defy us without consequence.
We monitored the battle transmissions. Kephess kept referring to his "masters." Any clue who he was talking about?
Whoever these "masters" are, they weren't on Denova.
None.
We have intel on forces invading Hutt Space. Could this be related?
Follow a puppet's strings far enough and there's usually a Sith holding them.
Could this be a Sith plot?
It would explain a great deal.
I wouldn't take his ranting too seriously. For all we know, he was just hearing voices in his head.
The Trandoshan was insane.
Regardless, you've done us a great service by eliminating him.
Empty victories, celebrated by dead heroes.
The Republic mistakes nightfall for dawn.
The six herald rebirth. Of power... order... domination.
Submit, and be spared. Resist, and be swept aside. Choose.
The Jedi will never submit--and we won't be swept aside. We will defend the Republic to our dying breath.
You've picked the wrong fight.
Your air grows thin.
Your negotiating skills leave much to be desired. May I offer you some instruction?
That's no choice at all.
Your taunts ring hollow.
Havoc Squad never backs down from a fight--and those robes look plenty flammable. I'd say the choice is yours.
That's not going to happen.
Empty-headed threats do not amuse.
"We will crush you," blah, blah, blah. Don't you Sith ever get sick of hearing yourselves talk?
Better idea: You shut up.
Cries in the darkness, mistaken for bravery. Fool.
How did you get in here? Identify yourselves.
Who are you?
We are fear. Horror. Doom.
When you put it like that, there's only one response.
Choose this. [Attack]
We are prisoners no more. Free of the Republic. Free of the Empire. Both will fall before the Dread Masters.
I will find you again, Republic children. Next time, you will die.
I've never felt fear like that before, not even as a Padawan. Who were those people? How is Kephess alive?
They appeared in my Senate chamber, as well. Security systems didn't register their presence.
But we know their names. The Dread Masters were powerful Sith serving the Emperor. They laid waste to whole fleets during the last war.
We imprisoned them on Belsavis. When the Empire stormed our maximum security wing, the Dread Masters broke free.
They're no longer serving the Empire. They want the galaxy all for themselves.
But now they're on their own.
I won't have this. I want them dead.
Escaping their cells is one thing--how did they get off the planet? We had ships in orbit.
How did they get away?
As you just experienced, these aren't ordinary Sith.
Imprisonment is no longer an option. Time to kill that scum.
This time, we execute them.
I couldn't agree more.
I'm calling an emergency meeting of High Command. When the Dread Masters resurface, we'll be ready.
Until then, remain vigilant. I will contact you when we know more.
You should go. I'll coordinate our forces landing on Denova. We're going to need that baradium.
The shuttle to Denova is standing by. We'll monitor your progress as best we can. May the Force be with you.
Captain Exteen, Jedi Knight and commanding officer of the Vanguard's Blade. Welcome.
This is a genuine honor. I flew bombing runs on Darth Angral's battle cruiser when he attacked Tython. That's a fight I'll never forget.
There were far too few Jedi starfighters in the sky that day. The Force was with you to survive against those odds.
Nice to meet a fellow veteran.
Once you boarded his ship, Darth Angral didn't stand a chance.
I was far from Tython when that battle occurred. When this mission is over, perhaps you two can tell me about it?
I want to hear about this.
I'd be honored, Master. I'd just arrived for my final trials the day you saved Tython's ancient Forge.
How did a Jedi fighter pilot wind up in charge of a Republic cruiser? Did you even go through officer training school?
Interesting career you've had.
Piloting a chair strapped to a bunch of bombs... that takes a special kind of crazy.
Fighter jockeys amuse me.
It was much worse than it sounds, Captain--and it's a pleasure to meet you. Master Sumalee praised your actions on Corellia.
Master, it's an honor. I'd just arrived on Tython when you saved the ancient Forge from Nalen Raloch. Your trials inspired all the Padawans.
So much has happened since those days. My battle with Nalen Raloch feels like another life.
That was a long time ago.
Masters at the temple still talk about what you did then--and everything since.
It's hard to believe the Jedi trials were ever our biggest worry. Of course, neither of ours were exactly by the book....
We've all come a long way.
I'm surrounded by heroes. I flew bombing runs on Darth Angral's battle cruiser over Tython. Quite a day.
You Jedi have all the luck. For my first mission, my CO sold me out to the Empire.
Your trials sound easy.
You remade Havoc Squad into the greatest special ops team in the Republic, Major. I've tried to follow your example.
I don't know what half those words meant, but you sure make them sound fancy.
I suppose I'm impressed.
Captain, it's a pleasure. Master Sumalee told me about your heroism on Corellia.
Major, it's an honor to serve Havoc Squad. When I assumed command, I learned everything about military service by studying your career.
Datapads won't teach you how to be a soldier. You only learn that in the field.
Then you didn't learn much.
Yes, sir. That's why I logged two hundred deep recon missions before accepting this promotion.
It's rare to see a Jedi focused on the art of war.
You seem right at home here.
I flew bombing runs on Darth Angral's cruiser when he attacked Tython. Your victory over him inspired me to follow this path.
The major is impressive, but I hope we won't need his expertise. Peace should always be a Jedi's first path.
War is never our best choice.
As you learned saving the ancient Forge, peace is only possible when both sides pursue it. I'm honored to meet you, Master.
That's great, kid--but there's more to this galaxy than uniforms and salutes. I'll show you how to retire a rich man.
Now learn from me.
Unnecessary, Captain--but it's a pleasure. I heard of your heroism on Corellia from Master Sumalee.
You're becoming a celebrity even in Jedi circles, Captain. Master Sumalee can't stop talking about you.
I knew she had a thing for me. Even Jedi women find me irresistible.
Admit it. She thinks I'm cute.
You'd have to take that up with her.
I should call her. She still owes me a drink for what I did on Corellia.
She's my kind of Jedi.
She mentioned that, too. Master Sumalee is... unconventional.
Gaining a Jedi Master's respect is no small feat, Captain. I trust you achieved that through legitimate means?
Impressive, if true.
The hero of Tython. I flew bombing runs against Darth Angral's cruiser when he attacked our homeworld. Never thought I'd meet you in person.
Don't let the flattery go to your head, Captain. Jedi are above hero worship.
Jedi don't have celebrities.
That isn't entirely true. I was a Padawan when you saved the ancient Forge on Tython, Master--and I'm truly honored to meet you.
I love going on missions with celebrities. They're great at drawing fire.
The captain can take point.
Major, it's an honor to meet you in person. Your mission records were required reading when I joined the military.
When High Command said special reinforcements were coming, I wasn't expecting anyone so high profile. Your accomplishments are legendary to my troops.
I'm just doing what I can to win this war. Becoming a celebrity wasn't part of the plan.
No need to flatter me.
Regardless, it'll be an honor to see you in action.
It's an honor just to serve. We're all heroes in this war.
No need to flatter me.
I don't know how you maintain that humility, considering all you've done.
I didn't realize Jedi were serving in the Republic military these days. How does that work?
You're a Jedi soldier?
I'm part of a new program initiated by Chancellor Saresh to integrate the Jedi Order and Republic military.
We're not here to reminisce. What's the situation?
No time for pleasantries.
Stand by. We're making the jump to hyperspace. I'll continue your briefing on arrival.
Launch delta wing. Initiate aerial reconnaissance.
This is Denova. Republic scouts discovered it last year. An unremarkable planet, except for its vast deposits of baradium--a key component in high-yield explosives.
Three months ago, the Empire discovered Denova's location, learned of the baradium deposits, and invaded.
I assume this substance we're fighting over is rare enough to warrant a major assault?
Baradium must be worth a lot.
Our stockpile of rockets and torpedoes is running out. We can't resupply our ground and space forces without more baradium. Neither can the Empire.
I don't see any Imperial warships in orbit. If the enemy is still on Denova, they must have landed some heavy forces.
Tell me about the invaders.
The Empire lacks enough ships to control the airspace--so they landed an entire armored battalion.
The Supreme Chancellor took her sweet time sending reinforcements. Why the holdup?
We're late to the party.
Until last week, we had defenders holding off the Empire.
We couldn't spare our own forces to secure Denova, so we contracted a Trandoshan mercenary army: the Warstalkers. Tough warriors. Never lost a fight.
The Warstalkers' leader, Kephess, has honored every contract he's taken--he's no Imperial sympathizer. His betrayal caught us completely off guard.
Mercenaries work for the highest bidder. Obviously, the Empire offered Kephess more.
It shouldn't have.
The Warstalkers aren't working for the Empire. They've gone rogue--and taken our enemies with them.
Was there anything in Kephess's background to suggest he'd turn against us?
What do we know about Kephess?
The Republic doesn't normally hire mercenaries to defend its territory, but Kephess had a reputation for loyalty. We don't know what changed.
None of those details matter. Kephess stabbed us in the back, and his Warstalkers will pay the price with him.
All traitors will die.
We aren't just facing traitorous mercenaries down there.
Kephess convinced the Imperial forces to desert the Empire and side with him. They've combined armies and declared Denova independent territory.
Republic children... you could not hold Denova--and Imperial fools will not take it. My masters gave me all I need to destroy you. Stay away, or die.
Sounds like Kephess isn't as trustworthy as he was cracked up to be--and he's taking orders from someone else.
So much for loyalty to us.
That's the strangest part. We've monitored Denova's communications since the invasion. This was the only transmission.
Who does Kephess serve? The Empire? The Hutts?
His masters?
No idea. We initially thought he was referring to the Trandoshan "Scorekeeper" deity, but this is something else.
I've met some overconfident fools in my time, but he is by far the ugliest. I'll enjoy putting him out of the galaxy's misery.
Don't count on it, freak.
I think that's the reaction High Command was hoping for.
The Supreme Chancellor's orders are clear: Take down Kephess and neutralize his army. The Republic needs Denova and its baradium stores.
A strike shuttle's waiting for you. This vessel and its fighters will provide support. May the Force be with us.
I'm overseeing a delicate op. Excuse me.
